issue.title: Single and Double quote doesn't render properly
issue.body:
### Issue Summary
I've tried [this link](https://www.mathjax.org/#demo) to view a latex equation. Which does not render properly, it rendered like [this](https://drive.google.com/file/d/12bgc5AZV2UDke6lRFlLTKG2A0yGcV0TT/view?usp=sharing), but it should render like [this](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1_rqn-HI9Yv_XeTs5mTvYpxzXFuk-mM9Z/view?usp=sharing).
I've also tried using MathJax version 3 by using below cdn, same things also happen there.

``` html
<script src="https://polyfill.io/v3/polyfill.min.js?features=es6"></script>
<script id="MathJax-script" async src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script>
```

The latex was: ‘P’ f"

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use above mentioned CDN.
2. Render $‘P’ f"$ this latex.

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 3
* Client OS: Windows 10
* Browser: Firefox, Chrome, Microsoft Edge

### MathJax Configuration:
MathJax = {
    chtml: {
        mtextInheritFont: true, 
    }
};


``` html
<script src="https://polyfill.io/v3/polyfill.min.js?features=es6"></script>
<script id="MathJax-script" async src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script>
```

issue.title: How MathJax works ?
issue.body:
Hi, I have a **question** and **suggestion**.

First i thank all the work team for that great job.

**My question** : How MathJax work ? if for example i have $\sum_{k=1}^{n} k$ in my page how mathJax render it to a mathematic formula. (I see the dev of 2.* versions and the use of images, but i can't figure it out how versions 3.* work)

**My Suggestion** : MathJax version 3 transform all Latex codes to mathematic formulas in the same time, then if we have a heavy page with a lot of LaTeX codes, then the page take lot of time to display mathematic formulas, i suggest to start rendring formulas from the top to bottom.

comment.body:
> My Suggestion : MathJax version 3 transform all Latex codes to mathematic formulas in the same time, then if we have a heavy page with a lot of LaTeX codes, then the page take lot of time to display mathematic formulas, i suggest to start rendring formulas from the top to bottom.

MathJax v3 has a lazy-typesetting extension that typesets only the math that is currently showing, and typesets additional math when it comes into the viewport.  That should make pages with lots of mathematics render more quickly.  See

	https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax-src/releases/tag/3.2.0#lazy

for more information.  Version 2 did use the approach you suggest, but it has some drawbacks as well.  The lazy typesetting feature seems to be the best solution at this point.

Davide

pull_request.title: Add <html>, <head>, and <body> tags to mathml when parsing as HTML
pull_request.body: The `linkedom` adaptor fails to parse MathML as an HTML snippet, so this PR adds tags to the MathML to make sure it is parsable as HTML.  This should not interfere with parsing in the browser or in LiteDOM, and is probably a good idea in any case.

pull_request.title: Add HTMLCollection to Window instance not constructor prototype
pull_request.body: This PR changes how the missing `HTMLCollection` is added to windows for linkedom.  In the past it was added to the Window class's prototype, but that seemed to interfere with SRE for some reason.  This is changed to add it to the window instance itself, as that is really all MathJax needs (it is used in `mathjax.document()` to determine if the data passed to it is an `HTMLCollection` as one of the options).

issue.title: v4-alpha, TeX: another array @{} issue

labels.name: Accepted
labels.description: Issue has been reproduced by MathJax team

issue.body:
E.g., `\begin {array}{@{}l@{}} a\\ b\end {array}` will eat up memory, e.g., causing hanging tabs and running out of memory on nodejs.

If I remove the (arguably weird) spaces before {array} or drop the @{}, things are fine.

comment.body: No problem.  At least it gives me an issue to tie the branch for the PR to.

issue.title: v4-alpha, TeX: another array @{} issue
issue.body:
E.g., `\begin {array}{@{}l@{}} a\\ b\end {array}` will eat up memory, e.g., causing hanging tabs and running out of memory on nodejs.

If I remove the (arguably weird) spaces before {array} or drop the @{}, things are fine.

comment.body:
As I mentioned in my email to you on November 21st, the issue is in the pattern at

https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax-src/blob/9d1370999feba6e608271b6309cb9d304c61b54a/ts/input/tex/base/BaseItems.ts#L1151

which needs a `\s*`

``` js
    const pattern = /^([^]*?)([&{}]|\\\\|\\(?:begin|end)\s*\{array\}|\\cr|\\)/;
```

I will make a PR for it.

issue.title: [tagformat] correct way to disable id generation entirely
issue.body:
This is more of a question but possibly something worth documenting.

We control the IDs across the document (and specify them in mathjax input via \cssId). We currently strip out mathjax-generated IDs in post processing (as they can cause trouble for us, e.g., duplicate IDs when cloning pieces of the document for UI purposes).

I was finally looking again to see if I could disable ID generation via the tagformat extension. It seems like specifying `id: () => undefined,` would work. 

I noticed that this caused some mild changes to the output - the hacky text element with `data-id-align` and the group with`data-idbox` was removed this way. Not a loss for us since we're not using them anyway (though it made me wonder why cssId is not using the same hack).

So I'm wondering if disabling id generation this way might have any drawbacks and/or if there is (or could be) a "proper" way to disable ID generation.

comment.body:
I took a look at the tagging code, and it looks like what you re doing is OK, as long as you aren't using `\ref` or `\eqref`, since they won't know what to link to.

> I noticed that this caused some mild changes to the output - the hacky text element with `data-id-align` and the group with `data-idbox` was removed this way.

Yes, those are generated for elements that have `id` attributes, but only when they don't fall on the baseline (that is, ones that are placed explicitly with a vertical offset).  So you *can* get those from your `\cssId` usage, but only if they are on certain kinds of elements.

The purpose of those is to allow WebKit to scroll to the correct location when the id is the target of a link, like for `\ref` and `\eqref`.

Merge pull request #877 from rhysd/expose-stylelist

Expose `StyleList` value contained in `Styles` object

pull_request.title: Expose `StyleList` value contained in `Styles` object
pull_request.body:
Today I have created a library to render Mathjax LiteDOM into React element tree.

https://github.com/rhysd/react-mathjax-component

One problem I'm facing is that there is no way to access to the key-value pairs of style value stored in `Styles` object. Since React element requires to specify styles through an object like `{maxWidth: '100px'}`, CSS text does not work. But `Styles` object only provides a way to get CSS styles as string. Currently my package [re-parses](https://github.com/rhysd/react-mathjax-component/blob/721b674b236786ad0517f897797df3b81f5bc8c5/litedom.ts#L14) the CSS text returned from `Styles` object but this is redundant (`Styles` generates a CSS string and my package restores the original key-value pairs of style object).

This PR fixes the problem by exposing the internal `StyleList` object.

issue.body:
### Issue Summary on iOS, writing multiple letters/words will show that they don't share a baseline. ### Steps to Reproduce: 1. use an iOS/iPad OS browser 2. write a formula containing multiple letters/words (seen best when using \text{}) 3. Observe misalignment I checked this on Windows, but this issue isn't observable there. ### Technical details: * MathJax Version: 3.2 * Client OS: iPadOS 16.1.1 * Browser: Chrome 108.0.5359.52 I tested this in the JsBin example, loading MathJax via ``` html ``` ### Supporting information: * Example html: ```html

When \(a \ne 0\), there are two solutions to \(\text{this will be badly formatted}\) and they are \[x = {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \over 2a}.\]

``` * Don't know if this will stay, but here's a [JSBin link](https://jsbin.com/vabudayifi/edit?html,output) * Screenshot of the bug: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/65970327/205168756-0e29c33c-cc61-42d3-86c7-bafd775b3cf7.jpeg)

comment.body: This is a long-standing issue with WebKit, and is a duplicate of #2866.  Potential work-arounds are given there.

issue.title: Subscripts and superscripts are incorrectly sized inside SVG when `font-size` is set on `<foreignObject>`

labels.name: Expected Behavior
labels.description: This is how MathJax works

labels.name: Code Example
labels.description: Contains an illustrative code example, solution, or work-around

issue.body:
### Issue Summary When `style="font-size: ..."` is set on a `` tag inside of an SVG, subscripts and superscripts are incorrectly sized (see the screenshot below). ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/98110034/205403103-8f3e346f-df98-4bf0-9292-86d858a97595.png) When no `style="font-size: ..."` is set on the ``, this bug does not appear. The problem exists both for SVG as well as CHTML output, although the size and positioning appears to be slightly different in each case. ### Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open the HTML below (or open this [fiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/np8fo4j2/)). 2. Observe subscript and superscript sizing inside of SVG. ### Technical details: * MathJax Version: 3.2.2 * Client OS: Linux 64-bit * Browsers: - Chromium 107.0.5304.121 - Firefox 107.0 - Microsoft Edge 106.0.1370.47 I am using the following MathJax configuration: None and loading MathJax via ``` html ``` ### Supporting information: HTML file: ```html
Outside SVG: \(\int_a^b f(x)dx\)
```

comment.body: Yes, the value used for `scriptminsize` should be reconsidered.  Since it is already changed from the MathML specification, it should be changed to a value that works in more situations.

pull_request.title: Only activate explorer if in a browser
pull_request.body:
This PR sets the `enableExplorer` option to `false` if there is no `window` variable, so that it is only activated in interactive contexts, and puts off creating the RegionPool until it is needed (in case it is not enabled).  Now that the explorer is included as part of the combined components, it needs to play nice with node-based applications that use the combined configurations, so references to the `window` and to HTML element properties can cause problems.

I started to cover the explorer files to use generics rather than explicit `HTMLElement` references and use the DOMAdaptor to handle the HTML interaction.  But because some pieces of SRE itself use HTMLElements directly, that probably is not worth it, as even if the MathJax portions are properly handled, the SRE parts could still fail.

The changes here are enough to avoid errors when using the examples in the "simple" directory of the MathJax-demos-node repository.

pull_request.title: Fix parsing of vertical bar delimiters in physics package (mathjax/MathJax#2973)
pull_request.body:
This PR fixes the parsing of `|` delimiters in the physics package.  The code that tests for nested delimiters was considering the closing `|` to be the opening delimiter of a nested set of `|` delimiters, leading to an error about missing close delimiters.  The solution is to put the check for nested delimiters *after* the check for closing delimiter to allow for open and close delimiters to be the same character.

Resolves issue mathjax/MathJax#2973.

issue.title: Automatic bracing cannot be used with vertical bars in `physics` extension

labels.name: Accepted
labels.description: Issue has been reproduced by MathJax team

issue.body:
### Issue Summary

The auto-bracing command `\qty` does not work with vertical bars (though `\vqty` works)

Admittedly `\qty|a+b|` is a somewhat odd thing to try to use and might be sufficiently rare that it doesn't warrant fixing in MathJax, but it does catch me off guard every now and then and does deviate from the reference implementation of `physics`.

The documentation for the LaTeX `physics` package can be found on [CTAN](http://mirrors.ibiblio.org/CTAN/macros/latex/contrib/physics/physics.pdf)

Note that the `physics` package needs to be loaded. I couldn't find a demo page that has this loaded by default, unfortunately.

### Steps to Reproduce:
```md
This does not render
$$
\qty|a+b|
$$

This renders fine
$$
\vqty{a+b}
$$
```

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 3.2.2
* Client OS: Windows
* Browser: Electron Application (Chromium)

comment.body: OK, it turns out that the code that looks for nested delimiters is causing this problem, and is treating the close `|` like a nested open `|`.  There is an easy fix, and I will make a PR for it.  If you need a patch in the meantime, let me know I can give you a configuration that fixes it.

issue.title: Numbered, centered, long equations are incorrectly indented

labels.name: Expected Behavior
labels.description: This is how MathJax works

labels.name: Code Example
labels.description: Contains an illustrative code example, solution, or work-around

issue.body: ### Issue Summary Numbered, centered, long equations are indented even though they shouldn't be. This means that long equations are flowing into the margin much sooner than they should be. Here is a screenshot: ### Steps to Reproduce: Please open the attached HTML file (see at the bottom). The issue **does not occur when equations are {unnumbered and centered} or {numbered and left-aligned}** (via `displayAlign: 'left'`). The issue occurs both with SVG and CHTML. ### Technical details: * MathJax Version: 3.2.2 (according to `MathJax.version` in browser console) * Tested with the following browsers: - Firefox 105.0.3 (64-bit) - Chromium 106.0.5249.119 (Official Build) Arch Linux (64-bit) - Microsoft Edge Version 106.0.1370.47 (Official build) (64-bit) I am using the following MathJax configuration: ``` js MathJax = { tex: { tags: 'all' } } ``` and loading MathJax via ``` html ``` ### Feature request In addition to fixing this bug, it would be great if MathJax were able to put the equation number below the equation for long equations, like LaTeX does: I can open a feature request for this separately should this be desired. ### HTML file ``` html Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. \[ \left(1+x\right)^n = 1 + nx + \frac{n\left(n-1\right)}{2!}x^2 + \frac{n\left(n-1\right)\left(n-2\right)}{3!}x^3 + \frac{n\left(n-1\right)\left(n-2\right)\left(n-3\right)}{4!}x^4 + \ldots \] Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. ```

comment.body: > Why would it be harder to get it to work with SVG output? There are two reasons. First, we have kept the SVG output to a single SVG in the past, as an important use case is to use MathJax to generate SVG versions of the math to be used with `` tags or inserted into EPUB and other formats where having a single image is helpful. Using two SVG tags, as you suggest, would also require the containing element, and additional CSS to be present, and that would break a number of these use cases. Second, your approach works for single equations with single equation numbers, but some numbered environments include equation numbers for each line in the alignment, and the equation numbers would need to float independently, and would need to force the lines of the alignment to separate when one of them floats down to the next line. I may be able to get that to work in the HTML layout, but that would be much harder to accomplish with the SVG output; each line would have to be a separate SVG, and that leads to an even more complicated container layout, again meaning that the single-SVG expectation would be broken. While may be possible to work that out, I'm not sure that the trade-off between the widely used single-SVG and this functionality is worth it.

issue.title: Rendering issue for "extenders" in chtml output seen also in Chrome 100. SVG output seems to avoid the issue
issue.body:
### Issue Summary

Issues where `\left|`, `\right|`, and `\overline` are not appearing in `chtml` output at certain zoom levels have now been observed in Chrome 100.0.4896.60. At least one report seems to have been about such an issue in Chrome 99.0.4844.84.

Prior issues of this nature have been reported in the past in Firefox, and at least the `\overline` issue has been confirmed as a bug in Firefox.

I am not aware of any reports of this nature for Chrome in the recent past until those brought to my attention in the last few days. I suspect that some recent update to Chrome may have lead to this display issue starting to occur in Chrome only recently.

The current recommended workaround is to use the `svg` output mode instead of `chtml`. That seems to solve the problems both in Chrome and in Firefox.

Related issues for Firefox:
  - https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax/issues/2795 
  - https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax/issues/2732
  - https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax/issues/2741
  - https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax/issues/2844

Firefox bug report: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1741887

### Steps to Reproduce:

The problem was seen in MathJax rendered equations in WeBWorK 2.16 (MathJax 3.1.2) for the equation
```
\left| \, \left( z_1 \cdot z_2 - \overline{z_3} \, \right)^3 \, \right|
```
with the `\overline` disappearing at some zoom levels, and the `\left|` and `\right|` at others. On one Windows 10 PC all were missing at the 200% zoom level.

Another formula using `\left|` and `\right|` was seen to also trigger the same issue.

Changing to SVG output works and the formula which encountered problems rendered properly at all zoom levels which were legible.

See:
  - https://github.com/openwebwork/webwork2/issues/1524


### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 3.1.2 (in WeBWorK 2.16)
* Client OS: Windows 10
* Browser: Chrome 100.0.4896.60 (64-bit)

comment.body:
The fonts have been overhauled for v4, and I think they should work better for these situations.  At least they do for my testing.  I would not file a bug at this point.

The difference between the fraction line and the underline is that the underline uses the `transform` attribute to stretch a character in a font, while the fraction line is a CSS border.

comment.body:

This would be a reasonable project for a third-party extension, if anyone is interested.

issue.title: Github Mathjax chokes on the expression $g^{\frac {p-1} {{p_i}^{n_i}}}$
issue.body:
### Issue Summary

Github Mathjax chokes on the expression `$g^{\frac {p-1} {{p_i}^{n_i}}}$`  in the build phase.

### Steps to Reproduce:

Use the expression `$g^{\frac {p-1} {{p_i}^{n_i}}\$`  in a github page where you import Mathjax. The page errors out while building.
This is the build error I get.

```
github-pages 227 | Error:  Liquid syntax error (line 3): Variable '{{p_i}' was not properly terminated with regexp: /\}\}/
```

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: Latest
Client & Browser version aren't relevant because this is a build issue.


I am using the following MathJax configuration:

``` js
<script type="text/x-mathjax-config">
  MathJax.Hub.Config({
    tex2jax: {
      inlineMath: [ ['$','$'], ["\\(","\\)"] ],
      processEscapes: true
    }
  });
```

and loading MathJax via

``` html
</script>

<script type="text/javascript" charset="utf-8" src="[https://cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/latest/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS-MML_HTMLorMML](view-source:https://cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/latest/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS-MML_HTMLorMML)">
</script>

<script type="text/javascript" charset="utf-8" src="[https://vincenttam.github.io/javascripts/MathJaxLocal.js](view-source:https://vincenttam.github.io/javascripts/MathJaxLocal.js)">
</script>

```

### Supporting information:

1) When you save the page in github, the github preview renders it fine without errors. However when the page builds, it errors out.

2) There is a simple workaround to fix this - If you use `$g^{\frac {p-1} {p_i^{n_i}}}$` instead of `$g^{\frac {p-1} {{p_i}^{n_i}}}$`, it no longer chokes, but the other form also shouldn't choke.

comment.body:
As you point out, this is a build issue; MathJax isn't involved until the page is viewed in a browser, so it is not a MathJax problem, and there is nothing MathJax can do about it.

It appears that the Liquid Template for GitHub pages uses `{{ variable }}` to insert the value of a variable into your output, so that is conflicting with the use of braces in LaTeX notation.  The `{{` at the beginning of `{{p_i}...` is being picked up by the Liquid template as an attempted variable reference that isn't closed properly by `}}` since the next brace is a single brace.  You will need to either protect the braces in the math (perhaps via `\{`) or do something like insert spaces so that you have `{ {` rather than `{{` (I haven't tested either of those suggestions).

In any case, it is something that must be dealt with at the template level, as it occurs long before MathJax itself is involved.

issue.title: Use border styles rather than frame attribute for arrays with mixed solid/dashed/dotted frame, or missing sides
issue.body:
Currently, when an array has lines on all sides, the `mtable` gets a `frame` attribute with the style given by the left-hand side, which can switch the style of the other sides.  For example,

``` latex
\begin{array}{:c|}
\hline
a\\
\hline
\end{array}
```

produces an array with a dashed frame all around.  Now that v3 supports border styles properly, this would be better handled using the `style` attribute to set the border styles individually.

When an array has borders on only some of the sides, that is currently handled through an `menclose` element with the proper sides made solid.  This loses dashed or dotted lines, and uses different spacing, so that is not idea.  Again, using the `style` attribute to set borders would work better.

issue.title: SVG StyleList unused styles?
issue.body:
The styles for the SVG output include `.mjx-dashed` and `.mjx-dotted`:

https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax-src/blob/2911de7ab7d11861805f7ff3bfc1a27e6406d553/ts/output/svg/Wrappers/mtable.ts#L113-L119

Since I couldn't find any content with either class on the AMS end, I looked where these classes might get added - and didn't find anything. It looks like `addBorderBroken` does the job of handling these borders.

https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax-src/blob/f939f2ff2c4678785e9bf3d3b17e8c6151f0ce9c/ts/output/svg/Wrapper.ts#L272-L274

Perhaps the classes are leftovers from v2 or there was a later change or (more likely) I didn't spot where these classes are actually used.

comment.body:
These are used for the lines within a matrix (from the `rowlines` and `columnlines` attributes of `mtable`), and are created in the `lineClass()` function

https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax-src/blob/8565f9da973238e4c9571a86a4bcb281b1d98d9b/ts/output/svg/Wrappers/mtable.ts#L241-L243

It constructs the class name dynamically, which is why searching for `mjx-dashed` or `mjx-dotted` won't find it.

This method is used in the `makeFrame()`, `makeVLine()`, and `makeHLine()` methods that follow it.

DO NOT simply erase the form and type a free-form response.** ----- ### Issue Summary I encounter a scenario : \hspace.5cm have NO horizontal shift effect but \hspace3em DO have shift effect ### Steps to Reproduce: 1. This is the simple html ```html

``` 2. It appear as: 3. After press the left button, it appear 4. console.log report: <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" jax="CHTML" tabindex="0" ctxtmenu_counter="2" style="position: relative;"><mjx-math class="MJX-TEX" aria-hidden="true"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D434 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mspace></mjx-mspace><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D435 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml unselectable="on" display="inline"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mspace width=".5cm"></mspace><mi>B</mi></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> 5. After press the right button, it appear 6. console.log report:<mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" jax="CHTML" tabindex="0" ctxtmenu_counter="3" style="position: relative;"><mjx-math class="MJX-TEX" aria-hidden="true"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D434 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mspace style="width: 3em;"></mjx-mspace><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D435 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml unselectable="on" display="inline"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi><mspace width="3em"></mspace><mi>B</mi></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> 7. Why \hspace.5cm have no shift effect, but \hspace3em HAVE shift effect Any other information you want to share that is relevant to the issue being reported. Especially, why do you consider this to be a bug? What do you expect to happen instead? ### Technical details: * MathJax Version: 3.2 * Client OS: (e.g., Windows 10 21H2) * Browser: (e.g., Chrome 106.0.5249.119) I am using the following MathJax configuration: ``` js ``` and loading MathJax via ``` html ``` ### Supporting information: * Please supply a link to a (live) minimal example page, when possible. * If your issue is with the display of the mathematics produced by MathJax, include a screen snapshot that illustrates the problem, when possible. * Check your browser console window for any error messages, and include them here. * Include the MathJax configuration you are using, and the script tag that loads MathJax itself.

comment.body:
MathJax converts all units to `em`s internally, and in order to do that, MathJax must determine the size of the `em` unit where the math is being typeset.  You are creating an isolated `div` that is not part of the active DOM, and that means that the browser will not perform any layout, and in particular, all elements return a width and height of 0.  So when MathJax tries to determine the `em` size, it gets back 0.  So converting `cm` to `em` will end up with zero.  Units of `emus work because these don't have to be converted, and are used verbatim.

One solution would be to add the `div` to the DOM before typesetting it (you could use `visibility: hidden`, but should not use `display:none` as that has the same problem).  Alternatively, you could use `MathJax.tex2chtmlPromise()` to do the typesetting (though you would have to remove the delimiters).

issue.title: Numbers without text don't render when using tex2svg

labels.name: Accepted
labels.description: Issue has been reproduced by MathJax team

issue.body:
Running `node -r esm tex2svg 408` and `node -r esm tex2svg -30` generates:

```
<svg style="vertical-align: 0;" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="0.036ex" height="0.036ex" role="img" focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 16 16" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><defs><style>svg a{fill:blue;stroke:blue}[data-mml-node="merror"]>g{fill:red;stroke:red}[data-mml-node="merror"]>rect[data-background]{fill:yellow;stroke:none}[data-frame],[data-line]{stroke-width:70px;fill:none}.mjx-dashed{stroke-dasharray:140}.mjx-dotted{stroke-linecap:round;stroke-dasharray:0,140}use[data-c]{stroke-width:3px}</style></defs><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="scale(1,-1)"><g data-mml-node="math"></g></g></svg>
```

Which appears to be an empty svg

comment.body: OK, it turns out that the `yargs` command argument parsing turns arguments that are numbers into perl numbers rather than strings, since `MathJax.tex2svgPromise()` expects a string, then it is passed a number it doesn't parse properly.  So one solution would be to change `argv._[0]` to `String(argv._[0])` in the `tex2svg` command file.  I'm not sure which `tex2svg` you are using (there is one in most of the directories), but you should be able to fix the one you are using with that change.

issue.title: why mathjax in node 16, after init , mathjax is null

comment.body: Please see [this post](https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax/issues/2963#issuecomment-1319215195) for details.

issue.title: why false when user mathjax in node

comment.body:
Using MathJax in a browser versus in a server-side node application has some differences, and the mechanism you are using (importing mathjax and calling `mathjax.init()`) is set up as a quick way to get MathJax running in a command-line node application, but is not set up for browser use.  The "note" at the bottom of [this section](https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax-src#using-mathjax-components-in-node-applications) of the MathJax README file points this out.

To use MathJax in a browser you could import one of the MathJax combined components (e.g., 'tex-chtml.js'), which is set up for browser use, and then call the global variable `MathJax.tex2mmlPromise()` method.  Or you can look at the examples in the [MathJax node demos](https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax-demos-node) repository for examples of other ways to call MathJax.  For example, the "components" directory shows how to load component-based MathJax files, and the "direct" directory shows how to import that MathJax modules directly.  

For the component examples, you would want to leave out the `source` and `require` properties in the `loader` block of the configuration, and remove the `adaptors/LiteDOM` from the `load` array.  The "preload" directory might also be a good place to start.  

You can also look at the the [custom-component](https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax-demos-web/blob/master/custom-component/custom-component.html.md) example in the [MathJax web demos](https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax-demos-web) repository for an example of loading MathJax components into a custom application setting.

issue.title: Numbered, centered, long equations are incorrectly indented
issue.body: ### Issue Summary Numbered, centered, long equations are indented even though they shouldn't be. This means that long equations are flowing into the margin much sooner than they should be. Here is a screenshot: ### Steps to Reproduce: Please open the attached HTML file (see at the bottom). The issue **does not occur when equations are {unnumbered and centered} or {numbered and left-aligned}** (via `displayAlign: 'left'`). The issue occurs both with SVG and CHTML. ### Technical details: * MathJax Version: 3.2.2 (according to `MathJax.version` in browser console) * Tested with the following browsers: - Firefox 105.0.3 (64-bit) - Chromium 106.0.5249.119 (Official Build) Arch Linux (64-bit) - Microsoft Edge Version 106.0.1370.47 (Official build) (64-bit) I am using the following MathJax configuration: ``` js MathJax = { tex: { tags: 'all' } } ``` and loading MathJax via ``` html ``` ### Feature request In addition to fixing this bug, it would be great if MathJax were able to put the equation number below the equation for long equations, like LaTeX does: I can open a feature request for this separately should this be desired. ### HTML file ``` html Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. \[ \left(1+x\right)^n = 1 + nx + \frac{n\left(n-1\right)}{2!}x^2 + \frac{n\left(n-1\right)\left(n-2\right)}{3!}x^3 + \frac{n\left(n-1\right)\left(n-2\right)\left(n-3\right)}{4!}x^4 + \ldots \] Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. ```

comment.body:
While I understand your criticisms, there are some considerations in a dynamic HTML setting that are not issues in LaTeX itself. 

The equation numbers are set up so that they continue to be placed at the right when the browser window changes size, and so that the equation remains centered as that happens.  In order to properly center the equation (which should be done without regard to the presence or absence of an equation number), the equation numbers are set in a zero-width box so it doesn't affect the centering of the equation itself.  But in order to avoid having the equation overlap the equation number when the equation is long or the window is small, MathJax reserves space at the right of the equation for the equation number.  But to keep the equation centered, automatically, the same amount of space must be reserved on the left as well.  Unfortunately, that does mean that there will be space on the left in the situation you are having.

So at the moment, this is the expected behavior for MathJax.

As for the label moving down, again, the dynamic window sizing makes that hard to do, as it would have to be handled by CSS so that it moves down when the space gets too small, and I don't know of a way to do that.  Perhaps there is something in flex-box that can do that, but I'm not sure.

For the use-case where the width will not change (even if the window is resized), it would be possible to handle the centering in different ways to avoid the extra space and do the special equation number positioning, but that isn't currently available.

issue.title: PGML numeric lists should work with )
issue.body:
When creating a numeric list with PGML, the following doesn't work:

```
1) First
2) Second
3) Third
```

This does work with all other lists types I've tests, `a)`, `A)`, `i)`, and `I)`. So in order to create a numeric list `1.` is needed instead. To me this is inconsistent. Though the docs seem to only state `)` is usable with alpha characters (<https://webwork.maa.org/wiki/Lists_and_sub-lists_-_PGML>).

I think it would be useful if the above would create a list to be consistent with other lists. This one case being different at least caused me confusion for a bit.

comment.body:
It looks like the problem is 

https://github.com/openwebwork/pg/blob/27923e4770dd64bfa76b8dd15d0d8a9e8f0f4bdb/macros/PGML.pl#L155

which should be

``` perl
    /\d+[.)] /       && do {return $self->Bullet($token,"numeric")};
```

like the lines below it.  It might also be good to change

https://github.com/openwebwork/pg/blob/27923e4770dd64bfa76b8dd15d0d8a9e8f0f4bdb/macros/PGML.pl#L40

to be

``` perl
my $list = '(?:^|(?<=[\t ]))(?:[-+o*]|(?:\d+|[ivxl]+|[IVXL]+|[a-zA-Z])[.)]) +';
```

to allow multi-digit list numbers as input.

issue.title: Consider using FontFaceSet API for loading fonts (so you can tell when they are loaded)
issue.body: The `FontFaceSet` API seems to be available in all modern browsers, so consider using that to load and track web fonts, so we can tell when they are actually available (the CHTML output doesn't rely on knowing that, but it would be nice to be able to tell when the MathJax output is actually fully visible).

issue.title: Add ability to define active characters in the configmacros extension
issue.body: The `configmacros` extension allows macros and environments to be declared, but it would be nice to allow active-character macros as well so that a single character could be mapped to a replacement string.

issue.title: MathJax node does not work with HTML

comment.body:
The `MathJax.tex2chtml()` function takes a TeX string as its first argument, not a serialized HTML string, so it is processing the HTML tags and other text as mathematics, not HTML.  That is why your output includes italics, the dollar signs, and the tag names.  See the [documentation](https://docs.mathjax.org/en/latest/web/typeset.html#conversion-options-1) for more details.

> Does that mean we should use `npm i mathjax-node` for it to work on browsers, or are both implementations of mathjax-node the same, meaning neither are supposed to work on browsers?

The section of the readme you site refers to the use of `require('mathjax').init({...})`, not to MathJax v3 in general.  This technique is a quick way to get MathJax running in node, but it is set up to handle loading of extensions and other MathJax files using node's `require()` function, and to use the LiteDOM internally, while in-browser use requires a different method for loading extensions, and should use the browser DOM rather than the LiteDOM.

MathJax can be included into node programs in several different ways, and these are illustrated in the different directories in the [MathJax-demos-node](https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax-demos-node) repository (e.g., `component` and `direct`), and these can be used to pre-process math on the server.

This repository for `mathjax-node` is a v2-only hack that makes it possible to run MathJax v2 in a node application.  MathJax v3 was designed to be able to be used directly in node (with the proper configuration), so there is no need for mathjax-node if you are using v3.

issue.title: Numbers without text don't render when using tex2svg
issue.body:
Running `node -r esm tex2svg 408` and `node -r esm tex2svg -30` generates:

issue.title: npm run make-components fails on Windows
issue.body:
This is due to the fact that the `makeAll` output is piped to `grep`, which doesn't work in Windows shell.  Perhaps `makeAll` should have a switch that controls how much output to produce rather than using `grep`.

See [this post](https://groups.google.com/g/mathjax-users/c/iEQXsAM7E0w) for more details.

issue.title: Erroneous Subscript Rendering on a Github Repo Wiki
issue.body: ### Issue Summary When using certain combinations of LaTex commands on a Github repo Wiki page, subscripts fail to render (the text is instead rendered as normal full-size text). This issue seems to be only present when using MathJax through a Github Wiki page, if there is a better place I should be posting this report, please let me know. ### Steps to Reproduce: These all work as expected: A_1 A_1 = B_1 A_{1,2} = B_{1,2} Image of above: When `\hat{}` is added to the first variable, subscripts are ignored and simply rendered as normal text: \hat{A}_{1,2} = B_{1,2} \hat{A}_{1,2}B_{1,2} Image of above: These examples also render as expected: A_{1,2} = \hat{B}_{1,2} \hat{A}_{1,2} \hat{A}_{1,2}B_1 Image of above: ### Technical details: * MathJax Version: Can't find the version, just using on a Github repo's Wiki page * Client OS: Windows 10 * Browser: Chrome Version 106.0.5249.119 (Official Build) (64-bit) I don't know the MathJax configuration. ### Supporting information: I rendered the two failed examples [here](https://saxarona.github.io/mathjax-viewer/), and they work as expected:

comment.body:
This is an issue with how GitHub has hooked Mathjax into its Markdown processing.  Since Markdown uses underscores to indicate italics, it removes them and inserts HTML tags that produce italics.  MathJax doesn't process math that contains HTML tags.  If you look carefully at the "normal text" that you pasted into your report, you will see that the underscores are missing, and that the text between them are in italics.  That is why the math isn't being processed.

GitHub's implementation of MathJax tries to prevent the LaTeX from being processed by Markdown, but unfortunately, they didn't cover all the needed cases, and there are a number of bugs like this.  A workaround is to use `\_` rather than `_` so that Markdown won't process the underscores, but if GitHub ever fixes the problem, you might end up with explicit underscores in your math.

See [my response](https://github.com/community/community/discussions/36984#discussioncomment-3981018) to one of the bug reports in the GitHub discussions area.

issue.title: mathtools \overbracket doesn't respect \color in SVG output

labels.name: Accepted
labels.description: Issue has been reproduced by MathJax team

issue.body:
The math tools package's `\overbracket` doesn't properly handle the color set by `\color` in SVG output (but is OK in CHTML output).  E.g., `\color{red}{\overbraket{a}^{b}}` colors the `a` and `b`, but not the bracket itself.

This is due to having `fill="currentColor"` being set on the polygons that make up the bracket.  These should be left off so that the bracket will inherit the fill color from its parent elements.

testing more $\begin{bmatrix}X\\\Y\end{bmatrix}$

issue.title: mathtools \overbracket doesn't respect \color in SVG output

labels.name: Accepted
labels.description: Issue has been reproduced by MathJax team

issue.body:
The math tools package's `\overbracket` doesn't properly handle the color set by `\color` in SVG output (but is OK in CHTML output).  E.g., `\color{red}{\overbraket{a}^{b}}` colors the `a` and `b`, but not the bracket itself.

This is due to having `fill="currentColor"` being set on the polygons that make up the bracket.  These should be left off so that the bracket will inherit the fill color from its parent elements.

issue.title: [SVG][mathtools] multlined in aligned rendering poorly
issue.body:
Here's a rather involved real world use case:

```
\begin{equation}
 \begin{aligned}
[t] T_{{\mathbf{u}}, x} {\mathcal{V}}&= \begin{multlined}[t][.7\linewidth] \left\{ (\dot{{\mathbf{u}}}, \dot{x}) \in T_{\mathbf{u}}{\mathcal{U}}\times T_x {\mathbb{P}}^n\mathbin{|}\right. \\
 \left. \forall i, f_i \left( (\mathbf{1}_{\mathcal{U}}+ t \dot{u}_i + o(t))^{-1} (x+t \dot{x} + o(t)) \right) = o(t) \text{ as } t\to 0 \right\} \end{multlined}\\
 &= \left\{ (\dot{{\mathbf{u}}}, \dot{x}) \in T_{\mathbf{u}}{\mathcal{U}}\times T_x {\mathbb{P}}^n\mathbin{|}\forall i, f_i\left(x + t( \dot{x} - \dot{u}_i x) \right) = o(t) \text{  as } t\to 0 \right\}\\
 &= \left\{ (\dot{{\mathbf{u}}}, \dot{x}) \in T_{\mathbf{u}}{\mathcal{U}}\times T_x {\mathbb{P}}^n\mathbin{|}\forall i, \mathrm{d}_x f_i (\dot{x}) = \mathrm{d}_x f_i( \dot{u}_i x) \right\}. \end{aligned} \tag{17}\cssId{texmlid43}{}
\end{equation}
```

On https://www.mathjax.org/#demo, the SVG output renders poorly:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/426686/196149267-25df3388-8379-4671-ae8e-4b4c0876569e.png)

For comparison, the CSS output is:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/426686/196149429-75a28794-73eb-4d8c-9c22-30192c33fe48.png)

comment.body: The problem is the `.7\linewidth` as the width for the `mullioned` environment.  MathJax doesn't have `\linewidth`, and it doesn't do computations in the width in any case, so that end up being considered as a width of 0, I think.  Version 4 has a warning about this, but version 3 doesn't.  It does seem that the output is not consistent between the two renderers when the width is too short for the content.

issue.title: memory leak and infinite loop with <tex-html>

labels.name: Accepted
labels.description: Issue has been reproduced by MathJax team

issue.body:
### Issue Summary

I wanted to have a look at the v4 alpha, and set up a minimal page to try out the `<tex-html>` feature. It worked fine with one `<input>` tag in a `<tex-html>` tag inside a LaTeX expression, but having two tags locks up my browser and then makes it quit once the PC runs out of memory. I guess there's an infinite loop somewhere producing tonnes of memory, but it's hard to debug because my browser keeps crashing!

### Steps to Reproduce:

I've set up a page on glitch: https://glitch.com/edit/#!/mathjax-v4-testing?path=index.html%3A15%3A8

The only bit of LaTeX in the page is this:

```
\[ 
      \begin{pmatrix}
        <tex-html><input name="p00"></tex-html> & 0 \\
        <tex-html><input name="p11"></tex-html> & 0 \\
      \end{pmatrix}
      = 5
      \]
```

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 4.0.0-alpha.1
* Client OS: Ubuntu 22.04
* Browser: Firefox 105.0.3

I am using the following MathJax configuration:

``` js
MathJax = {
  loader: {load: ['[tex]/texhtml']},
  tex: {
      allowTexHTML: true,
      packages: {'[+]': ['texhtml']}
  }
};
```

and loading MathJax via

``` html
    <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@4.0.0-alpha.1/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script>
```

comment.body:
I have figured out what is happening, and have a fix that I will make as a PR.

For now, however, as a work-around, you can do `\newcommand{\HTML}{}` and put `\HTML before the second and subsequent `<tex-html>` tags.  That should make it work for now.

### Issue Summary
I've tried [this link](https://www.mathjax.org/#demo) to view a latex equation. Which does not render properly, it rendered like [this](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1XIgC_rbMh0z-MLw_y50MthPb795WaJOZ/view?usp=sharing), but it should render like [this](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1V3AZiPfKO4iGnwzjPfXsJjAb_0Y_fTOI/view?usp=sharing).
I've also tried using MathJax version 3 by using below cdn, same things also happen there.

``` html
<script src="https://polyfill.io/v3/polyfill.min.js?features=es6"></script>
<script id="MathJax-script" async src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script>
```

The latex was: `\left[\![ \begin{matrix}a\\b\\c\\\end{matrix}\right]\!]`
The latex that generate perfectly: `\left[\![ abcd\right]\!]`

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use above mentioned CDN.
2. Render `\left[\![ \begin{matrix}a\\b\\c\\\end{matrix}\right]\!]` this latex.

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 3
* Client OS: Windows 10
* Browser: Firefox, Chrome, Microsoft Edge

### MathJax Configuration:
```
MathJax = {
    chtml: {
        mtextInheritFont: true, 
    }
};
```


``` html
<script src="https://polyfill.io/v3/polyfill.min.js?features=es6"></script>
<script id="MathJax-script" async src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script>
```

comment.body:
This is the correct rendering for the LaTeX that you have used.  You are using a multi-character sequence to "fake" a double bracket, and `\left` and `\right` only work with single-character delimiters, and so they stretch only the first of the two brackets in each case..  So the output you show is the correct output, and what actual LaTeX would produce as well.

The MathJax TeX fonts don't include the double-bracket character, either as a single character, or as the parts needed to make a multi-character assembly.  Some of the fonts in v4.0 do, however, so you may be able to do better with that.

Alternatively, you could use

``` latex
\left[\!\!\!\left[ \begin{matrix}a\\b\\c\\\end{matrix}\right]\!\!\!\right]
```

to get the effect you are looking for.

issue.title: async in script breaking the equation

labels.name: Expected Behavior
labels.description: This is how MathJax works

issue.body:
### Issue Summary I've tried to render two equation in same page mentioned in below code. When I use async like `` No 1 equation got broken, but no. 2 equation renders perfectly. When I don't use async like `` No 2 equation got broken, but no. 1 equation renders perfectly. HTML Code: ``` HTML
  • \({\underset{\begin{matrix}|\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \\CH-N{O}_{2}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \\|\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \\{CH}_{2}-N{O}_{2}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \\\end{matrix}\ }{{CH}_{2}-N{O}_{2}}}\ \)
  • \(\text{ট্রান্সক্রিপশন}\)
``` ### Steps to Reproduce: 1. Run above mentioned html with async and without async ### Technical details: * MathJax Version: 3 * Client OS: Windows 10 * Browser: Firefox, Chrome, Microsoft Edge

comment.body:
The differences are due to the font inheritance, yes, but they are correct and not something to worry about.

> But the first equation still have extra space in middle line

This is due to the fact that you are trying to use spaces on the right to force the expression to be justified on the left.  That is not a very practical way to get the result you want.  You could use `\hfill` in place of the spaces to left-justify the entries in the matrix, or you could use the `array` environment instead of `matrix` as `\begin{array}{l}` so that the entries are left justified.  Using spaces for this is just a really bad idea.

issue.title: mathcal{o} does not render properly
issue.body:
### Issue Summary
I've tried [this link](https://www.mathjax.org/#demo) to view a latex equation. Which does not render properly, it rendered like $\mathcal{o}$, but it should render like [this](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fD4h6FUxhZLoRnHRYWFCN3H_bZcQwIJS/view?usp=sharing).
I've also tried using MathJax version 3 by using below cdn, same things also happen there.

``` html
<script src="https://polyfill.io/v3/polyfill.min.js?features=es6"></script>
<script id="MathJax-script" async src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script>
```

The latex was: \mathcal{o}

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use above mentioned CDN.
2. Render \mathcal{o} this latex.

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 3
* Client OS: Windows 10
* Browser: Firefox, Chrome, Microsoft Edge

### MathJax Configuration:
```
MathJax = {
    chtml: {
        mtextInheritFont: true, 
    }
};
```


``` html
<script src="https://polyfill.io/v3/polyfill.min.js?features=es6"></script>
<script id="MathJax-script" async src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script>
```

comment.body:
The MathJax TeX fonts used in v3 (and by default in version 2) don't include lower-case calligraphic characters, so MathJax can't produce the one you are asking for and falls back on the standard italic characters.  Indeed, even in LaTeX, `\mathcal{o}` won't produce that character without specifying a font set that includes it (by default, it doesn't even produce an "o" of any kind).

MathJax v4.0 (now in alpha release) includes 10 new fonts, some of which have lower-case calligraphic letters, such as the STIX2 fonts.  You can try it out if you want access to a wider range of characters.

<mjx-container class="MathJax" jax="CHTML" display="true"><mjx-math display="true" style="margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0;" class=" MJX-TEX"></mjx-math></mjx-container>

mathjax-full@3.2.2

comment.body:
Thanks, I can reproduce the issue and will look into it.

For now, these are just warnings, and you can ignore them for now.  They are printed to `stderr` not `stdout` so they won't be part of the captured output if you re redirecting to a file or piping to a program.

Alternatively, you can set

``` js
        versionWarnings: false
```

in the `loader` section of the MathJax configuration in `tex2chtml` to prevent the messages from being produced.

### Issue Summary

I discovered that I am experiencing some pretty severe font problems for MathJax in Firefox (version 102.2.0esr (64-bit)) but only when using a large monitor (24 in., 1920 x 1080 resolution). I also found the equations look bad at 100% Firefox browser zoom level but fine at 110%. The same equations look correct in Firefox on a smaller laptop monitor at 100% browser zoom level (14 in., 1920 x 1080 resolution). They also look correct in Chrome and Microsoft Edge on both my large and small monitors (also 100% browser zoom level). I typically use Chrome, so I’m not sure how long this issue could have been occurring (maybe the entire time I've been working w/ MathJax). Some of my colleagues see the same issue, and some can’t reproduce the issue (even when seemingly using the same settings and screen sizes).

The problem only occurs for the main MathJax display. It looks fine in the zoom pop-up box. The issue seems to at least affect stretchy fences, summation and product symbols, and square root symbols (there could be other things, though, too). The problem is not present when I change from Math Renderer HTML-CSS to SVG. I know in the past you've warned about HTML-CSS, but this is what we've retained on our website as the default as of now because for the most part we like the look of it. Is this problem just something we'd have to live with (for some people) if we want to stick w/ HTML-CSS mode, or is there anything else we could do to help it? Also, any idea why some of us see the issue and some of us don't? Thank you in advance!

issue.title: MathJax 4 warning and TeX conversion failure

labels.name: Expected Behavior
labels.description: This is how MathJax works

comment.body:
> I thought the MathJax.startup.defaultReady(); line at the start of the JS function was supposed to force a wait for MathJax to be ready. Did I misread the documentation or did it change in V4? 

You misread the documentation.  Javascript does not have the ability to "force a wait" for something without making the function that is doing the waiting into an asynchronous function itself (so whatever called it would need to wait for it, and whatever called that one would need to wait, and so on).  If javascript had that ability, there synchronization would be much easier, and you would not have the same need for promises that we do.  That need is built into the language, unfortunately, and is not really related to MathJax at all, as anything that would require a program to dynamically load something in a browser (as MathJax does) would need to deal with the fact that that loading is not synchronous, and that the program would have to deal with waiting for that using promises.

> It was working in V3.

That is because there was no asynchronous action during startup of v3.  Now that the explorer is included and active by default, that means enrichment by SRE is being performed, and so SRE must be ready to do the enrichment when you convert your mathematics.  But SRE needs to load its language translation maps, and even though those are packages with the combined component, the loading is mediated by promises, and those always are asynchronous, even if they can be resolved immediately.  (SRE can't tell whether the map files are packaged with it or not, and so always uses promises.)

Your use of `MathJax.startup.defaultReady();` is non-standard (it was designed to be used in the `ready()` function in the `startup` block of your MathJax configuration, and only to be called once), so using it as you do is unusual, and may be the cause of the problems you report in your other open issue.  One of the results of calling this will be to re-instantiate all MathJax's internal structures like the input and output jax and the main MathDocument object that kept track of the math that is in the page.  That does give you a "fresh" input processor that is unaffected by previous expressions, but it also gives you a new output jax, and that one will not know about the CSS created by the previous one, and so the dynamically created CSS that is used to control the CHTML output may well get messed up by this.

issue.title: `mathjax@4.0.0-alpha.1` should not be tagged as `latest`
issue.body:
### Issue Summary

`mathjax@4.0.0-alpha.1` is tagged as `latest` at the `npmjs.com` registry:

- https://www.npmjs.com/package/mathjax?activeTab=versions

 It should be tagged as `beta` or `dev`. Now, executing `npm i mathjax` installs `mathjax@4.0.0-alpha.1`.

See:

> By default, the latest tag is used by npm to identify the current version of a package, and npm install <pkg> (without any @<version> or @<tag> specifier) installs the latest tag. 

- https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v7/commands/npm-dist-tag#purpose

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: `mathjax@4.0.0-alpha.1`

comment.body: I believe I have reset the tags so that 3.2.2 is latest.  Thanks for the report and links.

issue.body:

```

The latex was: A{\buildrel{4F}\over{ \xrightarrow[\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ ]{}}}B

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use above mentioned CDN.
2. Render above mentioned latex.

### Technical details:

comment.body:
It looks like nested over-under constructions prevent the arrow from stretching.  I will have to look into that further.

I'm curious, however, why you don't use something like `A\xrightarrow{\ \ 4F\ \ }B` rather than the more complicated construct you are suing.  Or perhaps `A\xrightarrow{\mathmakebox[3em][c]{4F}}B` if you want more exact control over the width of the arrow (provided you load the math tools package for `\mathmakebox`).  These would work around the error you have reported.

issue.title: async in script breaking the equation
issue.body:
### Issue Summary I've tried to render two equation in same page mentioned in below code. When I use async like `` No 1 equation got broken, but no. 2 equation renders perfectly. When I don't use async like `` No 2 equation got broken, but no. 1 equation renders perfectly. HTML Code: ``` HTML
  • \({\underset{\begin{matrix}|\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \\CH-N{O}_{2}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \\|\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \\{CH}_{2}-N{O}_{2}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \\\end{matrix}\ }{{CH}_{2}-N{O}_{2}}}\ \)
  • \(\text{ট্রান্সক্রিপশন}\)
``` ### Steps to Reproduce: 1. Run above mentioned html with async and without async ### Technical details: * MathJax Version: 3 * Client OS: Windows 10 * Browser: Firefox, Chrome, Microsoft Edge

comment.body:
The configuration script should come **before** the script that loads `tex-mml-chtml.js` so that it is in place when MathJax starts up (see the [documentation](https://docs.mathjax.org/en/latest/web/configuration.html#configuration-using-an-in-line-script).  Without the `async` attribute, the configuration script will definitely be too late, and the `mtextInheritFont` configuration will not occur, so the second one will certainly not render properly.  With the `async` attribute, you might get away with the configuration following it, but there is no guarantee.  It works for me, but I'm not using Windows.

Try moving the configuration script to its correct location before the `tex-mml-chtml.js` script so you are sure it gets properly processed.

issue.title: MathJax 4 warning and TeX conversion failure
Mathjax3 does not support the syntax for '//' line breaks
issue.body:
### Issue Summary

  The MathJAX3 upgrade does not support the syntax for '//' line breaks, so we have to use things like $\displaylines{x = A + B \\ y = b + c}$ to wrap lines, which is not very nice to us. Is there any way to configure MathJAX3 to support '//'? 

### Technical details:

* MathJax Version: 3.2
* Client OS: (e.g., Mac OS X 10.8.4)
* Browser: (e.g., Chrome 29.0.1547.57)

I am using the following MathJax configuration:

``` js
MathJax = {
    tex: {
      inlineMath: [['$', '$']],   // inlineMath: [['$', '$'], ['\\(', '\\)']], // 行内公式选择符
      displayMath: [['$\begin', '\end$'], ['\\[\begin', '\end\\]']],
      processEscapes: true,
      processEnvironments: false,
      packages: ['base', 'ams', 'noerrors', 'noundefined', 'cancel', 'color', 'bbox', 'mhchem']
    },
    options: {
      skipHtmlTags: ['script', 'noscript', 'style', 'textarea', 'pre', 'code', 'a'],
      ignoreHtmlClass: 'comment-content'
    },
    loader: {
      load: ['[tex]/ams', '[tex]/noerrors', '[tex]/noundefined', '[tex]/cancel', '[tex]/color', '[tex]/bbox', '[tex]/mhchem']
    }
};
```

and loading MathJax via

``` html
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/mathjax@3/es5/tex-mml-chtml.js"></script>
```

### Supporting information:
Is there any syntax other than '//' that is not supported after upgrading to MathJAX3?  Or can you give me a copy of the latex syntax table supported by MathJax? Thank you!

comment.body:
This is a duplicate of #2312.

We have just released v4.0.0-alpha.1, which includes the line-breaking implementation.  You may wish to give that a try.

Also, I believe you mean `\\` rather than `//`, right?

There is a list of [supported LaTeX commands](https://docs.mathjax.org/en/latest/input/tex/macros/index.html) in the [MathJax documentation](https://docs.mathjax.org/en/latest/).

payload.description: Beautiful and accessible math in all browsers

release.name: MathJax v4.0.0-alpha.1
release.body:
This is the first alpha release of a major new version of MathJax.  This version add significant new functionality, including:

* Support for 11 different fonts, including the STIX2 font set, and a sans-serif font based on the Fira-Math font.
* Support for automatic and explicit line breaks in both display and in-line expressions, breaking of text elements, better breaking in tables and arrays, more array column specifiers for the array preamble, and TeX macros to control line breaking, indentation, and alignment, as well as more commands for making fixed-size boxes in which line breaking can occur.
* Support for HTML embedded in MathML and TeX expressions (e.g., you can insert form elements into the math).
* Improvements to the assistive support by including the expression explorer (activated) in all combined components.

See the [release notes])(https://github.com/mathjax/MathJax-src/releases/tag/4.0.0-alpha.1) for more details.
